item.title: Putin Loosens Ban on Protests in Sochi
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia eased a ban on public protests in Sochi before and during the Olympic Games there, although all demonstrations will require approval.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: Cambodian Police Clear Park Before Planned Protest
item.description: Cambodian police officers on Saturday cleared protesters from a Phnom Penh park that has been the staging ground for antigovernment demonstrations, and organizers canceled a planned Sunday rally.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY

item.title: The Lede: Inside the Tale of North Korea Execution by Ravenous Dog
item.description: Western news media pick up an old report that for the South Korean press, it seems, was too sensational.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG and CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Jang Song-thaek, in blue, being escorted in court on Dec. 12, 2013. He was later executed.

item.title: Deadly Violence Erupts During Rallies Across Egypt
item.description: At least 13 people were killed as violence broke out during Muslim Brotherhood marches just days before a planned referendum on a draft constitution.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:credit: Virginie Nguyen Hoang/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: People fled a public bus in Cairo on Friday after it was caught up in clashes between supporters of former President Mohamed Morsi and the police. At least 13 people were killed nationwide.

item.title: Returning of Refugees to Bulgaria Worries U.N.
item.description: The United Nations refugee agency urged European countries to stop sending back asylum seekers, many of them originally from Syria, because they face poor treatment in Bulgaria.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: U.S. Is Facing Hard Choices in South Sudan
item.description: With no plans for American military intervention, the United States is frantically brokering peace talks between the warring factions while trying to fortify a United Nations peacekeeping force.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: Fleeing the Bombs in Aleppo, Syria, and Ending Up in New Jersey
item.description: A Syrian family is in the vanguard of what is expected to be a small but gradually growing stream of refugees from the country’s war resettling in the United States this year.
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE
item.media:credit: Michael Kirby Smith for The New York Times
item.media:description: The United States, which has already provided about $1.3 billion in humanitarian assistance to the Syrian people, has resettled at least 87 Syrians since fiscal year 2012, State Department officials said.

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Madagascar: Election Results Released
item.description: A former finance minister, Hery Rajaonarimampianina, won Madagascar’s first presidential election since a coup in 2009, but his closest rival said the vote had been rigged.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: More Migrants Rescued at Sea
item.description: The Italian Navy has rescued more than 1,000 migrants from boats trying to reach Europe in the past two days, Italian authorities said Friday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Food Assistance Needed to Stave Off Hunger Crisis, Officials Say
item.description: The Agriculture Ministry said it was importing 150,000 tons of corn, the nation’s staple food, from neighboring South Africa to avert a food crisis as millions face starvation.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: The Lede: Syrians Protest Assad and Islamist Militants
item.description: Video and images posted online by Syrian activists appeared to show that anti-Islamist protesters took to the streets in the city of Aleppo and in rural areas near the Turkish border on Friday.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Mystery in Hezbollah Operative’s Life and Death
item.description: The assassination of Hassane Laqees, Hezbollah’s master technician and logistics expert, has exposed a convulsing region’s tangled and shifting alliances and enmities.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: A photograph of Hassane Laqees, a logistics expert for Hezbollah, was displayed at his funeral last month in Lebanon.

item.title: The Lede: Video and Images of the Crisis in South Sudan
item.description: Thousands have fled their homes in recent days as fighting between forces loyal to President Salva Kiir’s government have fought against a rebellion led by his former vice president.
item.dc:creator: By LIAM STACK

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Mexico: 6 Police Officers Charged in Death of U.S. Citizen in Custody
item.description: The man, Yeudi Estrada, was dead when he arrived at Police Headquarters in the resort of Playa del Carmen after his arrest, local prosecutors said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Business Briefing | Regulatory News: Canada Ends 3-Year Inquiry Into Libor
item.description: The investigation is one of several by global regulators into whether banks manipulated rates to increase derivatives prices.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: A Cult Motorcycle From India Takes On the World
item.description: With models like the Bullet — an Indian-made avatar of an old British brand — Royal Enfield is making waves even as the competition for midsize bikes is heating up.
item.dc:creator: By SAMANTH SUBRAMANIAN
item.media:description: The Royal Enfield Motors factory in Chennai, India. The brand sold nearly 175,000 motorcycles in 2013.

item.title: Fear Keeps Thousands of South Sudanese on the Run
item.description: People trying to escape the conflict described scenes where former friends are targeting one another.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:description: Living in a camp in Awerial, South Sudan, a mother and her child are among the thousands of people who have fled the recent fighting between government troops and rebel forces.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Once Labeled a Traitor, Korean Aims to Be a Hero
item.description: Hong Yoon-hee, whose 1950 treason conviction in South Korea was recently nullified, says, “The truth is I helped save South Korea during one of its most critical times.”
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hong Yoon-Hee at the National Institute of Korean History in Seoul.

item.title: Iraq Fighters, Qaeda Allies, Claim Falluja as New State
item.description: After what appeared to be a morning lull, Sunni fighters destroyed the Police Headquarters and mayor’s office as violence resumed.
item.dc:creator: By YASIR GHAZI and TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: Sunni militants in Falluja, where they destroyed the Police Headquarters and seized government buildings Friday.

item.title: German Politician’s Rush to Lobbying Brings Scorn
item.description: Ronald Pofalla, who ran the German chancellery, was reported to be taking a specially created lobbying post at the national rail network said to carry compensation of more than a million euros a year.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Ronald Pofalla, who ran the German chancellery, was reported to be taking a specially created post at the national rail network.

item.title: Qaeda-Linked Insurgents Clash With Other Rebels in Syria, as Schism Grows
item.description: The fighting punctuated a growing rift between seven homegrown rebel groups and a powerful Qaeda affiliate.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By HWAIDA SAAD and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Fighters from the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria. Members of that group and other rebels clashed in northern Syria on Friday.

item.title: World Brief | Middle East: Palestinian Teenager Dies of Wounds From Israeli Gunfire
item.description: The Israeli military said the teenager was one of a group of people who vandalized the fence between Israel and Gaza and ignored warnings to move back.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: In Britain, Housing Prices Rise the Fastest Since 2006
item.description: Prices rose 8.4 percent last year, the fastest pace since 2006, and mortgage approvals also hit a high level.
item.dc:creator: By JULIA WERDIGIER and DAVID JOLLY

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel and U.S. Test Interceptor Missile
item.description: The Israel and the United States carried out a second test of the advanced Arrow 3 antiballistic missile system over the Mediterranean Sea.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: World War II Bomb Kills One Person in Germany
item.description: A bulldozer operator set off the bomb during construction work in Euskirchen, near Bonn, the former capital, wounding at least 13 people.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS COTTRELL
